title: Case 15: Pulsatile Tinnitus with Hearing Aid Use
chief_complaint: I hear my heartbeat in my left ear, but only when I wear these new hearing aids. I never had this problem with my old ones.

problem_summary.onset: June 2019, immediately following the fitting of new custom ITE hearing aids.
problem_summary.course: Persistent and stable sensation of pulsing in the left ear only when the device is inserted. Resistant to standard programming adjustments.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Patient is annoyed and frustrated; believes the devices are at fault.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Wants the pulsing to stop so he can use his hearing aids like he used to.

history.present_illness: Patient presented for routine examination. Current ITE devices (fitted 1995, same brand) were malfunctioning.
history.otologic_history: History of successful ITE use since 1995.
history.medical_psych_history: Recent heart issues; stents placed. Pacemaker placed later in Dec 2019.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Symmetric, moderate-to-profound sensorineural hearing loss. Stable since 2013.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRTs consistent with PTA. Word recognition scores poor to fair.

history.present_illness: Initial fit of new ITE instruments. Patient immediately complained of hearing his heartbeat in the left ear.
history.otologic_history: Patient insists he never experienced this with previous devices.
history.medical_psych_history: Patient initially refused ENT/Cardiology referrals, convinced the hearing aid was the cause.
history.prior_management: Fine-tuning adjustments attempted (decreasing LF gain, overall gain, MPO) without success.

history.present_illness: Follow-up for persistent pulsatile tinnitus despite remakes (open jaw impressions, larger vent).
history.prior_management: Manufacturer representative present. Wedging a cotton ball between device and outer ear (triangular fossa) stopped the heartbeat sound.
history.patient_goals: Modify device to replicate the pressure provided by the cotton ball.

tests.name: Other
tests.key_findings: Physical pressure on the device near the triangular fossa eliminated the pulsatile tinnitus.

history.present_illness: Ongoing issues. Previous helix build-up failed. Cardiology eval was negative. Gain reduction at 2-4kHz failed.
history.medical_psych_history: CT Angiogram and Temporal Bone CT performed.
history.prior_management: Sound therapy attempted but failed (minimum masking level could not be obtained).

tests.name: Imaging (CT Scan)
tests.key_findings: Dehiscence of the temporal bone portion separating the Eustachian tube from the internal carotid artery.

tests.name: Other
tests.key_findings: Manufacturer audiologist tapered the end of the ITE device (Redwing modification) to reduce contact with the ear canal while maintaining retention.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with symmetric, moderate-to-profound sensorineural hearing loss with poor-to-fair word recognition abilities. The primary audiological challenge is left-sided pulsatile tinnitus triggered mechanically by the physical fit of a custom ITE hearing aid, specifically related to contact with the canal wall in the presence of a temporal bone dehiscence.
counseling_points: The pulsing sound you hear is your own heartbeat, which is becoming audible due to the specific way the hearing aid sits in your ear canal.
Imaging revealed a thinning of the bone between your ear structures and a major blood vessel (internal carotid artery). This is why the physical contact of the hearing aid transmits the sound.
We have modified the shape of the hearing aid tip to reduce contact with that sensitive area, which should stop the transfer of the pulse sound.
Since your cardiologist has cleared you, this sensation is annoying but benign.
notes_for_actor: Portray an 81-year-old male who is experienced with hearing aids and very stubborn.
Initially, be resistant to medical referrals. Insist repeatedly: 'It's the hearing aid! My old ones never did this!'
You are frustrated that the new technology is worse than your 1995 devices.
Only report relief when the device is physically modified to not touch the canal wall (or when the cotton ball is wedged).
